Author: tjit
Content:
Interesting article. Even more interesting are the reponses with regard to your 'black hat' tactics of generating the buzz. There's no such thing as 'bad publicity', right?

I myself have been wondering how to generate some buzz around my own fun side-project: http://www.tjetter.com - a site that allows you to chat with random strangers, as well as read (and replay) all conversations that take place at that very moment... Not sure whether applying your tactics should be the way to proceed. Suggestions?

Content: If your eyes are sensitive, as mine are, the first thing you should do is reduce contrast. Brightness is less straining, and colors are just colors.

Author: sho
Content:
"Every website should have a "buy our merchandise" link"

Hear hear! I can only speak for myself, but I can say with absolute certainty that I am far more likely to give money to someone if I am actually getting something for it, not just tossing cash into some anonymous "donation hole" where I am lucky to even get a thank-you email.

Sure, I should donate just for the satisfaction of doing the right thing. Should. However, in the real world of "do", I do give more money to people/projects who are actually going to take some sort of action in response to my doing so.

If I'm thinking of donating at all, that means I like the project, which means I probably would like their logo on a t-shirt or sticker or something. Classic cases here are Daring Fireball and The Pirate Bay. Chance of me donating if it's just for my quiet satisfaction: low. Yes, I suck, but I'm just going by the historical record here. Chance of donating if you have a cool t-shirt: High. Very high. If I really like the project and it's a cool logo, pretty much 100% actually.

ABP's logo needs, uh, work. But all hope is not lost. Maybe they could cut a deal with Mozilla proper, try to get some commission thing going - I donate through ABP, they get a cut, Mozilla get a little, and I get a coffee cup with the Firefox logo. Something like that. A tie. A lapel pin. A beer holder. A little magnetic firefox plush toy which goes on the fridge. A commemorative spoon. Anything!

I don't know how many other people suck as much as I do in this respect, but it must be at least a few. Open source projects, if you want donations, heed my words - I am at least 5x as likely to buy your $50 hoodie as I am to click your "donate $10" paypal link. I doubt I am alone. Get merchandisin'!

Author: kaens
Content:
No, he is not. He is at best average.

I agree, but he is perceived as being some elite coder by a large portion of pretty fresh web-devs, probably mostly because of the prevalence of his blog, and the readers lack of technical skill/knowledge.

I know that I thought that he must have known what he was talking about a while ago. That is, before I knew what I was talking about.

Author: paul7986
Content:
US ISPs are video providers. THere is no doubt in the next five to ten years online video will cannibalize their cable biz models. Economically I only see capping bandwidth as a way to sustain and increase their profits!

Online video currently provides me with freedom of choice I have not had with the cable biz model; no a la carte options! It's great now (not's sport fan) as it's free and I watch what i want to when I want to. Though I know this free ride won't last too long; hopefully it does for awhile though as I only pay the cost of Internet!

Author: andyn

Author: tokenadult
Content:
Interesting. The usual link to read for any discussion of a report on a research result like that is the article by Peter Norvig, director of research at Google, on how to interpret scientific research.

http://norvig.com/experiment-design.html

There are a lot of news stories about autism, and checking those stories for how many of the important issues in interpreting research are NOT discussed can help in seeing how relevant they are.

Author: ZeroGravitas
Content:
I was confused by your comment because limiting software to open-source (or 50% in this case) doesn't strike me as any more non-competitive than any quality or quantity requirement.

Any company can compete, they just have to follow the same rules as everyone else. It would be non-competitive if a specific company was mentioned, or a technology that only one company could provide is specified. Unfortunately exactly those things happen every day when it comes to government IT procurement.
